trial_identification.studytitle: A randomised, controlled evaluation of the beyondblue depression training program for aged care staff: Impact on the delivery of health care services for older people with depression
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised, controlled evaluation of the beyondblue depression training program for aged care staff: Impact on the delivery of health care services for older people with depression

interventions.interventions: The intervention is a training programme for care staff in the precognition and detection of depression. Personal carers in residential facilities and direct carers in community services will participate in five 1.5 hour training sessions over 5 weeks that provide information on the nature and prevalence of depression amongst the elderly, symtoms and comorbidities. They will be taught to use a simple checklist of depression symtomatology, how to communicate with older depressed people, how to respond to depression, and how to facilitate referral of depressed people to appropriate services. Registered Nurses (residential) and Case managers (community) will particpate in these four sessions and two further 2 hours sessions focused on the use of standardised instruments to assess for depression, and liaison with General Practitioners.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Improved self-efficacy in relation to caring for older people with depression as assessed by the Self-Efficacy in Working with Late-Life Depression Scale;
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at pre- and post-intervention, and 6 months follow-up

primaryOutcome.outcome: Improved detection rates of depression among their care recipients and a higher number of referrals to medical services
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at pre- and post-intervention, and 6 months follow-up

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Improved knowledge of late-life depression and more positive attitudes to the care of older people with depression, as measured by Knowledge of Late-Life Depression Scale and the Attitudes to Depression Questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at pre- and post-intervention, and 6 months follow-up

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Improved care practices as assessed by Scale of Nursing Performance, and by directly comparing carers' assessments of the levels of depression among a sample of 10 care recipients from each residential service with assessments made by a Clinical Psychologist who will use the Structured Clinical Interview Schedule for Axis I Disorders

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Care staff and care managers in community based aged care services and low level care residential facilities speak English
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Care staff who do not speak English

trial_design.concealment: Four low-level care residential facilities and four community aged care services, drawn from Benetas and Uniting Aged Care aged care services, will take part in this study. Services will be randomly allocated to either (a) the training group, who receive the ‘beyondblue depression training program for aged care staff’ (two residential and two community services), or (b) the wait list control group (n = 80 staff; two residential and two community services). Allocation is not concealed.
trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation will take place by coin-tossing

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The objective of our research program is to improve pathways to care for frail older people with depression. The aim of this project is to demonstrate the efficacy of the beyondblue depression training program for aged care staff, through a randomised controlled study across community and residential aged care services. The specific hypotheses that will be tested are that, when compared with a wait-list control group that receives no training, aged care staff: (i) will demonstrate improved knowledge of late-life depression and more positive attitudes to the care of older people with depression, (ii) will demonstrate improved detection rates of depression among their care recipients and a higher number of referrals to medical services, (iii) will report improved self-efficacy in relation to caring for older people with depression, perceive fewer barriers to the provision of such care, and demonstrate improved care practices.
